text:
Great write up, feels very cohesive. Very interested in this topic at the moment so here's a bit of my take if it helps.

Re: Jordy's point about interruptions - personally I think it's okay to 'interrupt' if the interruption adds value — if product-led content is done well, it won't feel like an interruption! As long as your product is a natural part of the 'story' it's actually a better experience for the reader because it will answer the main questions they have.

I think the Jobs To Be Done framework is a great way to approach it. If you're talking about your readers' JTBD but don't mention how they can actually do those JTBD (with your product), it's actually leaving a knowledge gap for the person reading.

I think it often helps to think in non-SaaS terms. E.g. if you have a post on "_how to maintain your bicycle_" but don't show someone the tools to actually keep the bike running well (i.e. with your product!), they'll leave and need to look up something like "_best puncture repair kits_" after reading because you've left holes in their knowledge. But, if you had showed your product and how useful it was in that mid/top of funnel article originally, going to your product would have been the natural next step - no need for them to go back to Google to fill the knowledge gap they still have.

If your product placements improve the education process, it'll help them solve their problem faster — which is a benefit for the reader.

Shared a few rough thoughts on the same concept a while back if you want to see my take:  <https://georgespetrequin.com/blog/saasify-blog-content>

Also mentioned a few bits about Hotjar's approach here and how integrating your product into traditionally TOFU content is a great way to build awareness for product and doesn't have to be done in a salesy way: <https://www.contentbulb.com/blog/hotjar-content-marketing-teardown>

text:
The trick is "how do you do that" — <@U017WRJTKF1>'s rating system is a good, simple way to start thinking about it.

If you start to unpack storytelling science, things can start to get more complex (read: interesting). I'm a big advocate of trying to find a way to integrate whatever you're selling into the core conflict of the story. Too many brands make their product/service a cheap plot device to a lazy story (this person wants to save money... WELL GUESS WHAT!)
